titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Josephine Napoleon Leary papers, 1875-1991 RL.11503
titlestmt.author: Heather McGowan; updated by Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-02-19 18:55:24 UTC.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers of Josephine Napoleon Leary contain financial and legal papers, correspondence, biographical materials, and photographs pertaining to the life and business ventures of African American businesswoman Josephine N. Leary and her daughter Clara Ryan. Records document her real estate and other business transactions the coastal town of Edenton, North Carolina, where they resided; the earliest deed dates back to 1875. There are also architectural and historical documents relating to Edenton. Photographs of Leary and Reeves family members date from 1895 to about 1935. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Josephine Napoleon Leary papers are arranged into seven small series: Legal Papers, Financial Papers, Coorespondence, Personal Papers, Biographical/Historical Material, Maps and Architetural Materials, and Photographs.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Josephine Napoleon Leary was born into slavery in Williamston, North Carolina around 1856. At age nine, she was emancipated. In 1873 she married her husband "Sweety" Archer Leary and they moved to Edenton, North Carolina and operated a barbershop. Mrs. Leary, skillfully navigating the real estate market, acquired six properties in Edenton by 1881 in the "Cheapside" historic district. In 1893, Edenton and the "Cheapside" district, experienced a fire that destroyed all of Leary's investments. After the fire, Leary rebuilt 421-423-425 South Broad Street. This signature building in downtown Edenton still bears the mark "J.N. Leary 1894." Leary was overcome by cancer at the turn of the 20th century and the cost of medical care forced her to sell several of her properties. She died in 1923. Three of her properties were inherited by her daughter, Clara Ryan (born about 1875), but Leary's estaate was mired in debt and unpaid mortgages. Leary's daughter Clara, who is listed as "mulatto" in the 1920 U.S. Census and then Black in the 1930 census, married Noah Ryan.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Josephine Napoleon Leary Papers were purchased by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library in 1991.
Accession 2002-0125 was received as a gift from the Historic Edenton State Historic Site in 2002.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Josephine Napoleon Leary papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Melissa Delbridge, May 1991. Encoded by Heather McGowan, September 2017. Updated by Paula Jeannet, February 2020.
Accessions described in this collection guide: 1991-0153, 2002-0125.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Josephine Leary papers chiefly comprise business papers relating to the properties she owned in Edenton, N.C., and to a barber shop operated by Leary and her husband; these records include deeds, the earliest of which dates to the 1870s; mortgage and estate papers; bank records; and bills and receipts. Other papers include correspondence to Leary, her daughter Clara C. Ryan, Clara's husband Noah Ryan, and Clara's son, Percy Reeves, as well as correspondence pertaining to legal matters and to Leary's estate.

A group of biographical and historical papers contain maps, pamphlets, and other information related to late 19th and early 20th century Edenton and to the Leary legacy. These date mostly from Leary's lifetime, but also include later secondary sources about Edenton and Leary. Included in this group are the original plans for the J.N. Leary building (1894) that still stands on Broad Street in downtown Edenton.

The collection is completed by a few undated writings by Leary, one of which seems to be a eulogy, and by a group of albumen and gelatin silver photographs of Leary and her family, including her daughter, her brother, an uncle, her grandson Percy Reeves, and his family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Legal documents pertaining to the buying of properties and mortgages. The majority of the documents are deeds of trust on the properties Leary bought and eventually sold. The earliest date, 1875, refers to a deed of that year naming Josephine Leary and her purchase of the "Cheshire store house" in Edenton. This property, as with many of Leary's other properties, probably was destroyed by the 1873 fire.

The legal documents also include the death certificate of Josephine Leary and the clerk superior court's appointment of Clara Ryan as the administer of Leary's estate. The legal documents after Leary's death are primarily concerned with Clara Ryan's payments of Leary's debts. Folder 4 contains preservation photocopies of several deeds and Leary's death certificate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Financial papers in the collection document Josephine Leary's business and personal finances, and include bank records, insurance papers, mortgage checks, and bill payments. The records also include documents that tell of the financial turmoil that followed her passing in 1923.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Receipts of Josephine Leary's payments on her mortgages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Josephine Leary's and Clara Ryan's tax receipts, receipt for purchased building materials, receipt for electric, water and ice bills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Receipts of Clara Ryan's business purchases, notices to Clara Ryan for unpaid bills, court of Edenton payment cards, telephone rental bill, receipt for the purchase of a casket, cement, funeral and herse, as well as a deposit list for a grave marker for Josephine Leary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bank records contain Josephine Leary's 1913-1917 bank account ledger, deposit slips from Josephine Leary and her daughter Clara Ryan, and a deposit slip from Clara Reeves. All bank records are from the Bank of Edenton, NC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The insurance papers include Clara Reeves' receipt book with payment slips for Metropolitan Life Insurance, Wood and Warren Insurance for Josephine Leary's estate, Noah Ryan's receipt book for Metropolitan Life Insurance, a Harford Fire Insurance Company policy for the barber shop, three Virginia Fire and Marine Insurance Company policies for Leary's property on Church Street, a receipt of Clara Ryan's recieved payment from Gate City Life Insurance Company, and lapsed insurance notifications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Checks stamped paid from both Josephine Leary and her daughter Clara Ryan's payments to various people and businesses. Also includes an empty checkbook with payment stubs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes letters to Josephine Leary, her daughter Clara Ryan, Noah Ryan, Clara's husband, and Percy Reeves, a later owner of the Leary's barber shop.

Letters to Josephine Leary include Edenton law firm Pruden, Bond, and Holland correspondence related to Leary's properties; a letter from Mrs. R.D. James; and a letter from M.N. Sawyer, a real estate agent.

Letters to Clara Ryan include correspondence with her husband Noah Ryan; a letter from the NC Department of Revenue making Clara the executor of Josephine Leary's estate; letters from her nieces Maggie and Lulu and her cousin Gary A. Jones; a letter from the Rich Square Institute offering her a job; letters from lawyers concerning her mother Josephine's estate; as well as letters from friends, including a Christmas card from Mr. and Mrs. Garrett. Letters to Noah Ryan include several letters from lawyers and the Undertaker's Supply Company about late payments. There are also two letters to Percy Reeves, one from his daughter Maggie and one from Floris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes two personal writings by Leary, as well as a ledger of names and addresses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The biographical/historical information comprises documents related to the history of the town of Edenton and Josephine Leary. The documents include: a pamphlet from Central Barber Shop (Leary's business); a ticket to the Edenton Amusement Blub banquet at the Colored Hotel; two historic Edenton brochures that feature Leary's properties; a biography of Leary's assumed father; an article about the economic and social development of Edenton; an article about the Edenton fire and the "Cheapside" neighborhood; a copy of the inheritance document that transferred property to Clara Ryan; a copy of a 1932 story on the Leary barber shop; an article about Leary's properties; and a copy of the "Representative House and Prominent Men of Edenton, NC," including names of individuals with whom Josephine Leary sold and bought properties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group contains the plans for the J.N. Leary Building on South Broad Street in Edenton (1894) and a building permit for Noah Ryan, Leary's son-in-law, to build on Leary's property. They also include an announcement by the Edenton Women's Club of a publication about the architecture in Edenton, titled Edenton: An Architectural Portrait.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Black-and-white photographs of Josephine Leary and her family consist of formal portraits and informal snapshots. Includes mounted albumen prints as well as early modern gelatin silver photographs. Family members include Percy Reeves, Clara Reeves, Octavius (Josephine's brother) and Mazuria Williams, and Mallie McDonald of the Reeves family; includes formal portraits of Josephine Leary.
Paper photocopies of the photographs, with names and dates, exist in a separate folder in the box. Copy negatives were produced at one time and placed in the reference department's negative file.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: The photographs have been scanned and are available for viewing through the link in this collection guide.
